name: names for fairyland
sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: The names for fairyland are numerous and varied, with many being found in Irish and Scottish sources. It isn't clear whether these names refer to different locations or are just different ways of describing the land’s features. The most common names include Mag Mell (“plain of honey”), Mag Mór (“great plain”), and Tir Fo Thuinn (“land under wave”). Fairyland is also often referred to as Tir Na Nog (“land of youth”), which emphasizes the enduring beauty of its inhabitants. However, in places where the pre-Christian gods were demoted into Fairies, there is still a sense of respect for these ancient powers. Hence, it is deemed dangerous to call them by their original names, and euphemisms are used, some vague, others flattering, such as "Them," "the Other Crowd," "the Good Folk," and "the Good Neighbors." In Scotland, the common phrase used was "the Guid Folk," while in Wales it was "Tylwyth Teg," which means "the Fair Family." On the Isle of Man, the fairies were referred to as "Ny Mooinjer Veggey," which means "the Little Kindred," "Ny Guillyn Beggey," which means "The Little Boys," and "Yn Sleih Veggey," which means "the Little People." This verbal habit originated in Celtic beliefs about the power of the word. An infamous tale describes how a man was abducted by the fairies just because he repeatedly used the term fairies instead of a euphemism when passing their abodes. (See Fairy KIDNAPPING).
